head.title: Elegy X. Winter.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 36-39.

l.emph: Sullen and sad, with all his rising train,

epigraph.bibl: Thomson.22 James Thomson, Winter. A Poem (London: N. Blandford for J Millan, 1726). The completed poem cycle, The Seasons, appeared in 1730. The full line reads “See, Winter comes to rule the varied year, / Sullen and sad, with all his rising train-- / Vapours, and clouds, and storms. Be these my theme” (ll.1-3).

lg.l: Thick rolling clouds involve the gloomy sky,33 Although no further connection has been established, this line is suggestively reminiscent of John Dryden: “Thick clouds of rolling smoke involve the skies” (The Aenied, [London: 1694], VIII.141).
The wind sounds dreary in the leafless shade,
The joyless plains in desolation lie,
And wintry tempests sweep the barren glade.
Ah me! how chang’d, how alter’d is the scene,
Where late the turf in flow’ry pride was crown’d,
Decaying nature saddens all the green,
And with’red herbs and foliage strew the ground.
No shepherd’s pipe, no ’plaining damsel’s voice,
No lovelorn nightingale renews her tale;
The grottoes echo, with a mournful noise,
And sound responsive to the wintry gale.
Quick from the low’ring clouds descends the show’r,
The swelling streams o’er precipices flow,
From clift to clift impetuously they pour,
And spread a deluge on the plains below.
The lonely shepherd wanders o’er the hill,
Seeking his shiv’ring flock, from field to field,
Or drives them to some muddy gurgling rill,
Whose banks an hospitable shelter yield.
The tim’rous hare limps aukward to her den,
Nor can the naked fields her wants supply;
The doleful plover skims the wat’ry fen,
And fills the air with many a dreary cry.
O surly winter, soon thy frigid pow’r
Has stript the verdure of each spreading tree,
Nor in the forest, nor the birchen bow’r,
Left any shelter for the muse or me.
Yet let me not at summer’s loss repine,
Or eager wish the vernal months to see,
While inward heart-felt happiness is mine,
The season sure has store of charms for me.
A little house kind fortune still bestows,
A safe asylum from the tempest’s pow’r,
An easy bed for indolent repose,
And choice of books to pass a vacant hour.
Here let me lie, in rest’s soft arms reclin’d,
And hear the jarring winds at distance howl,
By fancy’s ear to melody refin’d,
So sadly pleasing to the pensive soul.
Come, drousy Morpheus,44 Greek God of dreams. hover round my bed,
Shake downy influence from each silken wing,
O’er all my senses soft ideas shed,
And all thy airy pleasing visions bring.
O waft my fancy, in the midnight hours,
To where the fairy bands their revels keep,
Lead me enraptur’d through elysian bow’rs,
Where limpid streams in smooth meanders creep.
Ye Bards departed, mighty men of song,
Awake the harp, each wonted sound recall,
With flying fingers sweep the strings along,

And raise the joy in Cona’s echoing hall.55 An Ossianic formula: cf. “Etha’s echoing hall” (“Dar-Thula,” in Macpherson, Poems of Ossian), “Conmor’s echoing halls” (Macpherson, Temora), "Conmor's echoing hall" ("Sul-malla of Lumon," in Gaskell, The Poems of Ossian and Related Works) and "Caruls echoing halls" ("Colna-dona" in Gaskell), etc., etc.
Or come Philander,66 Male lover, not perjorative as in modern usage. [GT's note: See the character of Philander in Elegy II.] from the silent grave,
Come in a dream, dear youth, and visit me,
My long lost friend enraptur’d I’ll receive,
And bless the vision that restoreth thee.
